result.markdown:
---
title: "Quick revision quiz: Introduction to R and R Studio"
output: webexercises::webexercises_default
---






::: {.webex-check .webex-box}

What is the purpose of R scripts in the context of data analysis?
<select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value=''>To create interactive visualizations</option><option value=''>To organize files and folders on your computer</option><option value='answer'>To type and save analysis code for later use</option><option value=''>To display the output of R code immediately</option></select>

What does the Environment in R Studio primarily display?
<select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value=''>The R script files</option><option value=''>Publication-ready outputs</option><option value='answer'>Objects (data, analysis, plots) currently in memory</option><option value=''>The R package installation menu</option></select>

Which of the following is a reason to learn and use R?
<select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value=''>It is a closed-source software</option><option value=''>It is used exclusively by programmers</option><option value='answer'>It has a large number of packages and a wide community of users</option><option value=''>It doesn't require any coding skills</option></select>

How can you install an R package in R Studio?
<select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value=''>By clicking 'Load' in the Environment section</option><option value=''>By running the package's executable file</option><option value='answer'>By using the 'install.packages()' function</option><option value=''>By copying the package files to the working directory</option></select>

What does the 'Run' button do in R Studio?
<select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value=''>It compiles the R script into a standalone program</option><option value=''>It generates publication-ready outputs</option><option value='answer'>It runs the code in the R script</option><option value=''>It opens the R package manager</option></select>


How can you load a previously installed R package?
<select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value=''>By clicking the 'Load' button in the Console</option><option value=''>By typing 'install.packages()' in the Console</option><option value='answer'>By using the 'library(package_name)' command</option><option value=''>By copying the package files to the working directory</option></select>

True or False: You can work on multiple datasets at the same time using R / R Studio? <select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value='answer'>TRUE</option><option value=''>FALSE</option></select> 

What advantage does using R scripts for analysis provide?
<select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value=''>They enable real-time collaboration with other users</option><option value=''>They allow you to create complex interactive visualizations</option><option value='answer'>They encourage transparency and reproducibility of analysis</option><option value=''>They automatically generate publication-ready reports</option></select>


What is the main role of the R Console in R Studio?
<select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value=''>To create interactive visualizations</option><option value=''>To dispay objects in memory</option><option value=''>To organize and manage files in the workspace</option><option value='answer'>To provide an interactive environment to run R code</option></select>

"What is the difference between R and R Studio?
<select class='webex-select'><option value='blank'></option><option value='answer'>R is a statistical programming language, while R Studio is a software developed for using R to do analysis</option><option value=''>R is a data visualization tool, while R Studio is a statistical analysis software</option><option value=''>R is used for web development, while R Studio is used for machine learning</option><option value=''>R is the name of the software, while R Studio is a community forum</option></select>"

:::
